title: 113_hr3313
content: The Act titled "Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Mission Indians Land Transfer Act of 2013" authorizes the transfer of land in trust for the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Mission Indians. The Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Mission Indians Land Transfer Act of 2013 authorizes the transfer of land into trust for the Tribe, which will be administered as part of the Santa Ynez Indian Reservation in accordance with applicable laws. Placing the land into trust removes restrictions imposed by certain California State laws. The Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Mission Indians Land Transfer Act of 2013 authorizes the transfer of specified lands in Santa Barbara, California, into trust for the Tribe. The legal description of the lands includes parcels from Tract 18 and Tract 24, as recorded in official records. Parcel 3 in Santa Barbara, California, includes portions of APNs 141-230-23 and 141-140-10. It consists of lots 19 and 20 of Tract 18, and portions of lots 1, 2, 7, 8, 9, 10, and 15 through 20 of Tract 16. This legal description is based on a certificate of compliance recorded on December 5, 2001. Parcel 4 in Santa Barbara, California, includes lots 1 through 12 of Tract 25, while Parcel 5 includes a portion of lots 3 and 6 of Tract 16. These parcels are based on certificates of compliance recorded on December 5, 2001. Rack 3, as Map 4 in the office of the County Recorder, lies northeast of land granted to the State of California. This legal is made pursuant to a certificate of compliance recorded on December 5, 2001. The Act does not affect existing rights or claims of the Tribe to land, water rights, or existing rights-of-way. The Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Mission Indians are restricted from conducting gaming activities on land taken into trust for them, as per the Act. This includes activities claimed under inherent authority or federal laws such as the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. The Secretary of the Interior is defined as the term "Secretary" and the Tribe is defined as the Santa Ynez Band of Chumash Mission Indians.
